{"step_by_step_thinking": "The Hoover test is a physical examination maneuver used to test for malingering or functional weakness in a patient. The examiner places one hand under the patient's heel and asks the patient to raise the other leg. If the patient genuinely tries to raise the leg, the examiner will feel pressure on the hand under the heel of the other leg. Waddell's test is a set of signs used to detect non-organic or psychological component to chronic low back pain. O'Donoghue test is used to determine whether a patient's pain is due to an injury of the muscles or ligaments. McBride test is used to diagnose patellofemoral pain syndrome.", "answer_choice": "A"}
